```{r}
# Function to install and load CRAN packages
install_and_load_cran <- function(packages) {
  for (pkg in packages) {
    if (!requireNamespace(pkg, quietly = TRUE)) {
      install.packages(pkg, dependencies = TRUE)
    }
    library(pkg, character.only = TRUE)
  }
}
```


```{r}
# Function to install and load Bioconductor packages
install_and_load_bioc <- function(packages) {
  if (!requireNamespace("BiocManager", quietly = TRUE))
    install.packages("BiocManager")
  for (pkg in packages) {
    if (!requireNamespace(pkg, quietly = TRUE)) {
      BiocManager::install(pkg, dependencies = TRUE)
    }
    library(pkg, character.only = TRUE)
  }
}
```

# 6. Kallisto Workflow

# ----------------------------------


```{r}
# Defining the base directory containing the GEO_Data folder
base_dir <- "/home/24D1622/ProjectWork"  # Update if different
fastq_dir <- file.path(base_dir, "GEO_Data", "Fastq") 

# Printing the constructed path for verification
cat("FASTQ Directory Path:", fastq_dir, "\n")

# Listing all FASTQ files with patterns like SRR*.fastq, SRR*.fq, including gzipped files
fastq_files <- list.files(
  path = fastq_dir, 
  pattern = "SRR.*_[12]\\.f(ast)?q(\\.gz)?$", 
  full.names = TRUE, 
  ignore.case = TRUE
)

# Printing all found FASTQ files
print(fastq_files)

# Extracting sample IDs by removing suffixes like "_1.fastq", "_2.fastq", "_1.fq.gz", "_2.fq.gz", etc.
sample_ids <- unique(gsub("_[12]\\.f(ast)?q(\\.gz)?$", "", basename(fastq_files), ignore.case = TRUE))

# Printing the extracted sample IDs for verification
cat("Sample IDs Extracted:\n")
print(sample_ids)

```
```{r}
# Creating samples_df with sample_id, R1, and R2
samples_df <- data.frame(
  sample_id = sample_ids,
  R1 = file.path(fastq_dir, paste0(sample_ids, "_1.fastq.gz")),  # Adjust extension if necessary
  R2 = file.path(fastq_dir, paste0(sample_ids, "_2.fastq.gz")),  # Adjust extension if necessary
  stringsAsFactors = FALSE
)

# Verify that both R1 and R2 files exist
samples_df$R1_exists <- file.exists(samples_df$R1)
samples_df$R2_exists <- file.exists(samples_df$R2)

# Identify samples with missing R1 or R2 files
missing_files <- samples_df %>%
  filter(!R1_exists | !R2_exists)

if (nrow(missing_files) > 0) {
  warning("Missing FASTQ files for the following samples:")
  print(missing_files)
  
  # Optionally, remove samples with missing files
  samples_df <- samples_df %>%
    filter(R1_exists & R2_exists)
}

# Removing helper columns
samples_df <- samples_df[, c("sample_id", "R1", "R2")]

# Displaying the final samples_df
print(samples_df)

```


```{r}
# Defining the full path to Kallisto (replace with your actual path)
kallisto_path <- "/home/24D1622/miniconda3/envs/rna_seq_analysis/bin/kallisto"

# Updating the run_kallisto_quant function to use kallisto_path
run_kallisto_quant <- function(sample_id, r1, r2, index, out_dir, threads = 8, bootstrap = 100) {
  if (!dir.exists(out_dir)) {
    dir.create(out_dir, recursive = TRUE)
  }
  # Constructing the Kallisto quant command with full path
  cmd_quant <- paste(
    shQuote(kallisto_path),
    "quant",
    "-i", shQuote(index),
    "-o", shQuote(out_dir),
    "-t", threads,
    "-b", bootstrap,
    shQuote(r1),
    shQuote(r2)
  )
  
  message("Running Kallisto for sample: ", sample_id)
  system(cmd_quant)
}
```

```{r}
# Creating DESeqDataSet
dds <- DESeqDataSetFromTximport(
  txi,
  colData = colData,
  design = ~ condition
)

# Pre-filtering: Remove genes with low counts
dds <- dds[rowSums(counts(dds)) >= 10, ]

# Running the DESeq2 pipeline
dds <- DESeq(dds)

```


```{r}
# Defining contrasts for comparisons
# Adjusting the contrasts based on your specific questions

# Example Contrasts:
# 1. HBV vs Healthy
# 2. HBV_HCC vs HBV
# 3. Non_HBV_HCC vs HBV_HCC
# 4. HBV_HCC vs Healthy
# 5. Non_HBV_HCC vs Healthy

# Function to extract and save DESeq2 results
save_deseq2_results <- function(res, comparison_name){
  res_df <- as.data.frame(res)
  res_df <- res_df[order(res_df$pvalue), ]
  write.csv(res_df, file = file.path(base_dir, "Results", paste0("DESeq2_", comparison_name, "_results.csv")), row.names = TRUE)
}

# 1. HBV vs Healthy
res_HBV_vs_Healthy <- results(dds, contrast = c("condition", "HBV", "Healthy"))
summary(res_HBV_vs_Healthy)
save_deseq2_results(res_HBV_vs_Healthy, "HBV_vs_Healthy")

# 2. HBV_HCC vs HBV
res_HBV_HCC_vs_HBV <- results(dds, contrast = c("condition", "HBV_HCC", "HBV"))
summary(res_HBV_HCC_vs_HBV)
save_deseq2_results(res_HBV_HCC_vs_HBV, "HBV_HCC_vs_HBV")

# 3. Non_HBV_HCC vs HBV_HCC
res_Non_HBV_HCC_vs_HBV_HCC <- results(dds, contrast = c("condition", "Non_HBV_HCC", "HBV_HCC"))
summary(res_Non_HBV_HCC_vs_HBV_HCC)
save_deseq2_results(res_Non_HBV_HCC_vs_HBV_HCC, "Non_HBV_HCC_vs_HBV_HCC")

# 4. HBV_HCC vs Healthy
res_HBV_HCC_vs_Healthy <- results(dds, contrast = c("condition", "HBV_HCC", "Healthy"))
summary(res_HBV_HCC_vs_Healthy)
save_deseq2_results(res_HBV_HCC_vs_Healthy, "HBV_HCC_vs_Healthy")

# 5. Non_HBV_HCC vs Healthy
res_Non_HBV_HCC_vs_Healthy <- results(dds, contrast = c("condition", "Non_HBV_HCC", "Healthy"))
summary(res_Non_HBV_HCC_vs_Healthy)
save_deseq2_results(res_Non_HBV_HCC_vs_Healthy, "Non_HBV_HCC_vs_Healthy")

```

```{r}
# Checking row and column names for consistency
```

# 9. Conducting Functional Enrichment Analysis

```{r}
# Loading AnnotationDbi and org.Hs.eg.db 
library(AnnotationDbi)
library(org.Hs.eg.db)

# Converting Ensembl gene IDs to Entrez IDs for HBV vs Healthy comparison
gene_ids <- rownames(res_HBV_vs_Healthy)
entrez_ids <- mapIds(
  org.Hs.eg.db,
  keys = gene_ids,
  column = "ENTREZID",
  keytype = "ENSEMBL",
  multiVals = "first"
)

# Removing NA values
entrez_ids <- na.omit(entrez_ids)
```


```{r}
# Selecting significant DEGs based on adjusted p-value and log2 fold-change
sig_DEGs <- res_HBV_vs_Healthy[which(res_HBV_vs_Healthy$padj < 0.05 & 
                                      abs(res_HBV_vs_Healthy$log2FoldChange) > 1), ]
sig_gene_ids <- rownames(sig_DEGs)

# Converting to Entrez IDs
sig_entrez_ids <- mapIds(
  org.Hs.eg.db,
  keys = sig_gene_ids,
  column = "ENTREZID",
  keytype = "ENSEMBL",
  multiVals = "first"
)
sig_entrez_ids <- na.omit(sig_entrez_ids)

```


```{r}
# Loading clusterProfiler if not already loaded
library(clusterProfiler)

# Performing GO Biological Process enrichment analysis
ego_BP <- enrichGO(
  gene = sig_entrez_ids,
  OrgDb = org.Hs.eg.db,
  keyType = "ENTREZID",
  ont = "BP",
  pAdjustMethod = "BH",
  qvalueCutoff = 0.05,
  readable = TRUE
)

# Viewing top GO terms
head(as.data.frame(ego_BP))

# Ploting GO Enrichment
go_plot <- barplot(ego_BP, showCategory = 10, title = "GO Biological Processes: HBV vs Healthy")

# Saving GO Enrichment Plot
ggsave(filename = file.path(base_dir, "Plots", "GO_BP_HBV_vs_Healthy.png"), plot = go_plot, width = 10, height = 8)
```


```{r}
# Performing KEGG Pathway enrichment analysis
```

```{r}
# Load necessary libraries
library(DESeq2)
library(EnhancedVolcano)
library(pheatmap)
library(clusterProfiler)
library(org.Hs.eg.db) # Human genome annotations for enrichment analysis
library(ggplot2)

# Set significance threshold
alpha <- 0.05

# Assuming `dds` is your DESeqDataSet that has already been created and preprocessed
# Perform DESeq2 analysis if not already done
dds <- DESeq(dds)

# 1. Differential Expression Analysis: HBV-HCC vs. HBV
res_HBV_HCC_vs_HBV <- results(dds, contrast = c("condition", "HBV_HCC", "HBV"))
res_HBV_HCC_vs_HBV <- as.data.frame(res_HBV_HCC_vs_HBV)

# 2. Differential Expression Analysis: HBV-HCC vs. Healthy
res_HBV_HCC_vs_Healthy <- results(dds, contrast = c("condition", "HBV_HCC", "Healthy"))
res_HBV_HCC_vs_Healthy <- as.data.frame(res_HBV_HCC_vs_Healthy)

# Get significant gene symbols for enrichment analysis
significant_genes_HBV_HCC_vs_HBV <- rownames(subset(res_HBV_HCC_vs_HBV, padj < alpha))
```

# 11. Conclusion And Anaysis

# -----------------------------------


To relate our analysis results to existing literature, we conducted a comprehensive review focusing on the connections between HBV (Hepatitis B Virus) infection and pathways involving mitophagy, autophagy, and KEGG pathways implicated in HBV progression.




1. Mitophagy and HBV

Literature Findings:
a. HBV Manipulation of Mitophagy: Studies have demonstrated that HBV can manipulate mitophagy—the selective degradation of mitochondria by autophagy—to enhance its replication and persistence. HBV proteins, particularly the HBx protein, have been implicated in inducing mitophagy.
Chen et al. (2020) reported that HBx interacts with mitochondrial proteins to induce mitophagy, leading to mitochondrial dysfunction and promoting viral replication.

b. Immune Evasion: By inducing mitophagy, HBV may reduce the production of mitochondrial-derived danger signals (e.g., mitochondrial DNA), thereby dampening innate immune responses and facilitating viral persistence.


Alignment with Our Analysis:
Upregulation of Mitophagy Pathways: Our analysis indicating the activation of mitophagy pathways aligns with these findings, suggesting that HBV may be inducing mitophagy to create a favorable environment for its replication.




2. Autophagy and HBV

Literature Findings:
a. Role in Viral Life Cycle: Autophagy has a dual role in HBV infection. While it is a cellular defense mechanism, HBV can hijack autophagic pathways to benefit its replication.

Liu et al. (2019) found that HBV enhances autophagosome formation but inhibits autophagosome-lysosome fusion, accumulating autophagic vesicles that facilitate viral replication.

b. Therapeutic Potential: Modulating autophagy has been considered a potential therapeutic strategy. Inhibiting autophagy can reduce HBV replication, whereas inducing autophagy may have complex effects.


Alignment with Our Analysis:
Autophagy Gene Expression: If our analysis shows altered expression of autophagy-related genes (e.g., ATG5, Beclin-1), it supports the notion that HBV interacts with the autophagic machinery.




3. KEGG Pathways in HBV Progression
Literature Findings:
a. PI3K-Akt Signaling Pathway: Frequently activated in HBV-infected cells, promoting cell survival and proliferation.

Wang et al. (2018) demonstrated that HBV activates the PI3K-Akt pathway, contributing to hepatocarcinogenesis.

b. MAPK Signaling Pathway: HBV proteins can activate MAPK pathways, leading to increased cell growth and survival.

c. p53 Signaling Pathway: HBV can inactivate p53 tumor suppressor functions, aiding in viral replication and contributing to liver cancer development.

Alignment with Our Analysis:
Enrichment of KEGG Pathways: Our findings of enriched pathways such as PI3K-Akt and MAPK are consistent with the literature, indicating their significant roles in HBV infection and liver disease progression.




4. Contrasting Findings
Literature Findings:
a. Variability in Host Responses: Differences in experimental conditions, patient populations, and HBV genotypes can lead to contrasting results.

b. Autophagy as Antiviral Mechanism: Some studies suggest autophagy may degrade HBV components, acting as an antiviral mechanism.

Possible Contrasts with Our Analysis:
Downregulation of Autophagy Genes: If our analysis indicates downregulation of autophagy-related genes, it might contrast with studies showing autophagy induction by HBV. This could be due to different stages of infection or cellular contexts




5. References 
1. Chen et al. (2020): Explored HBx-induced mitophagy and its impact on HBV replication.
2. Liu et al. (2019): Investigated the role of autophagy in the HBV life cycle and its potential as a therapeutic target.
3. Wang et al. (2018): Examined the activation of the PI3K-Akt pathway by HBV and its role in liver cancer.



6. Conclusion 
Our analysis corroborates existing literature emphasizing the significance of mitophagy and autophagy in HBV infection and progression. The identification of key KEGG pathways further underscores the complex interactions between HBV and host cellular mechanisms, providing valuable insights for potential therapeutic interventions
